questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in patients with malabsorption syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Constipation is not a feature of malabsorption syndrome. Malabsorption syndrome refers to a spectrum of conditions of various etiologies that arises due to 
diminished absorption of one or more dietary nutrients. The general features of malabsorption syndrome are abdominal pain, diarrhea, steatorrhea, and 
weight loss. Anemia may be present when there is defective absorption of iron, folate, or vitamin B12. 
Hypocalcemia and tetany can be seen due to defective absorption of vitamin D.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following tests is useful for the assessment of intestinal mucosal function in a 
patient presenting with symptoms of malabsorption?
questions.explanation:
D-xylose test is useful for the assessment of intestinal mucosal function. D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa without 
undergoing enzymatic digestion. 426 
Sold by @itachibot The test is performed by administering 25g of D-xylose orally followed by the collection of urine 
5h later. The test is considered abnormal (positive) if urinary D-xylose is <4.5g. A positive 
D-xylose test indicates abnormal small intestinal mucosa.

questions.question:
Question 3: The result of a D-xylose test showed urinary excretion of the monosaccharide at 3.6g after 5 
hours. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A urinary D-xylose <4.5g after 5 hours of oral D-xylose (abnormal) can be seen in Crohn’s 
disease. D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without 
undergoing enzymatic digestion. An abnormal (positive) D-xylose test indicates abnormal small 
intestinal mucosal absorption. A positive D-xylose test is seen in: • Celiac disease • Whipple’s disease • Tropical sprue • Short bowel syndrome • Crohn’s disease The test is of limited clinical value today and mostly has been replaced by small intestinal biopsy.

questions.question: Question 4: Patients with which of the following conditions are likely to suffer from malabsorption?
questions.explanation:
A small bowel diverticulum can result in malabsorption. A small bowel diverticulum is a blind pouch protruding from the small intestine that 
communicates with the lumen of the gut. It becomes a potential site for bacterial overgrowth 
which causes malabsorption. The growing gut bacteria depletes vitamin B12 and deconjugates bile 
acids leading to steatorrhea, diarrhea, and macrocytic anemia. Anterior colon resection, ulcerative colitis, and sigmoid volvulus affect the large intestine and 
therefore do not cause malabsorption.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common cause of short bowel syndrome in adults?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of short bowel syndrome in adults is mesenteric vascular occlusion. Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a malabsorption disorder caused by a lack of functional small 
intestine. In adults, the common causes are : • Mesenteric vascular disease (e.g: mesenteric vascular occlusion.) • Primary mucosal and submucosal disease (e.g: Crohn’s disease) • Operations without any preexisting small-intestinal disease (e.g: after trauma) 427 
Sold by @itachibot In children, necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common cause.

questions.question: Question 6: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to have protein malabsorption?
questions.explanation:
Homocystinuria is not a protein malabsorption disorder. It is a disorder of methionine 
metabolism that leads to increased homocysteine levels. Proteins are broken down by pancreatic enzymes and are absorbed as amino acids and peptides. 
So, protein malabsorption usually occurs only in pancreatic insufficiency. Additionally, there are 
three rare genetic disorders that lead to protein malabsorption. They are: • Enterokinase deficiency- Defective conversion of the proenzyme trypsinogen to trypsin. It is 
characterised by: • Diarrhoea • Growth retardation • Hypoproteinemia • Hartnup disease- Defective transport of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids. It is 
characterised by: • Pellagra-like rash • Neuropsychiatric symptoms • Cystinuria- Defective transport of cystine and other dibasic amino acids. It is characterised by: • Renal calculi • Chronic pancreatitis

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea. D-xylose test was normal and the 
Schilling test was abnormal. A duodenal biopsy was normal. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario describes a case of malabsorption syndrome (chronic diarrhea and 
steatorrhea), a normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy with abnormal schilling test points 
towards pancreatic insufficiency. A normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy rules out small intestinal pathologies like celiac 
disease (option A) and intestinal lymphangiectasia (option C), presence of steatorrhea rules out 
ulcerative colitis (option B) as it affects the large bowel which is not the main site of absorption of 
fat. 428 
Sold by @itachibot Ileal disease is also characterized by normal xylose test, normal duodenal biopsy and steatorrhea 
and abnormal schilling test but among the given options the most appropriate answer would be 
pancreatic insufficiency due to chronic pancreatitis. Pancreatic insufficiency is characterised by the deficiency of exocrine pancreatic enzymes that 
result in maldigestion and malabsorption. The features in favor of the diagnosis: • Steatorrhea - a deficiency of pancreatic lipases can lead to undigested fat in stools. • D-xylose test - d-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa 
without undergoing any enzymatic action. Normal d-xylose test denotes intact mucosa. • Schilling test - it is abnormal as pancreatic enzymes are required for the absorption of vitamin 
B12. Diagnosis of various malabsorption syndromes: Pathologies

questions.question:
Question 9: An 11-year-old boy presented with steatorrhea and chronic diarrhea. An evaluation revealed 
delayed intellectual development and ataxia. Acanthocytes were seen on the peripheral blood 
smear. Ophthalmological examination showed the following. Which of the following is the 
most likely diagnosis? 419 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image showing retinitis pigmentosa and presence of acanthocytes along with the given clinical 
features is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. 
Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea and diarrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, 
ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.

questions.question: Question 10: The findings associated with abetalipoproteinemia are :
questions.explanation:
Figure A shows vacuoles (unabsorbed fat) in the cytoplasm of the enterocytes. Figure B 
shows acanthocytes. These findings are associated with abetalipoproteinemia. 429 
Sold by @itachibot Figure C shows distended macrophages in the lamina propria and periodic acid–Schiff 
(PAS)-positive granules as seen in Whipple's disease. Acanthocytes are abnormal red blood cells with spiked cell membranes due to thorn-like 
projections. Causes of acanthocytes in peripheral smear are: • Abetalipoproteinemia • Renal disease • Liver disease • Hemolytic anemia 430 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: All are true about the types of celiac disease except :

options.a: Latent type is associated with HLA DQ 2,8
options.b: Atypical type has a negative serology
options.c: Silent type has a positive serology
options.d: Classic type presents with diarrhea and steatorrhea

questions.explanation:
Atypical celiac disease has a positive serology with atypical symptoms. Serology in celiac disease refers to either anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG) or 
anti-endomysial antibodies. Note: Tropical sprue and celiac disease have similar clinical, endoscopic and histologic findings. A 
diagnosis of tropical sprue must be considered with a negative celiac serology. Features Type of celiac disease

questions.question: Question 12: What is the most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis (DH). DH is characterized by intensely pruritic small papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of 
extremities, buttocks, and neck. It can be considered a celiac disease of the skin. Other extraintestinal manifestations of celiac disease are: • Anemia 431 
Sold by @itachibot • Low bone density • Ataxia • Peripheral neuropathy • Infertility Celiac disease is often associated with other conditions such as type 1 diabetes mellitus, 
autoimmune thyroid disease, IgA deficiency, bird fancier's lung, and Down syndrome. The image below shows dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, bone pain, and 
abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. 
Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation?
questions.explanation:
The presence of fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss and abdominal distention along with 
investigations showing features of malabsorption (iron deficiency) lead to the diagnosis of celiac 
disease or gluten sensitive enteropathy. The single best test for which is checking serum for the 
presence of IgA tissue transglutaminase (anti-TTG) antibodies (Option D). Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage 
to the proximal intestinal mucosa (villous atrophy) and malabsorption of nutrients. Symptoms usually begin 6 to 24 months from the introduction of gluten into diet, although most 
patients go undiagnosed. The common manifestations are - irritability, abdominal distention, chronic diarrhea, weight loss 
or muscle wasting and extra-intestinally, the symptoms observed are aphthous ulcers, delayed 
puberty, iron deficiency anemia and short stature. Screening for celiac disease is by testing for tissue transglutaminase IgA, endomysial, and 
deamidated antigliadin antibodies. IgA levels in serum are measured to detect false-negative 
results because of IgA deficiency. Small intestinal biopsy shows characteristic villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and increased 
intraepithelial lymphocytes. 432 
Sold by @itachibot The treatment involves the exclusion of gluten-containing food from diet. Long term complications observed are osteoporosis, anemia, infertility and malignancy 
(enteropathy related-T cell lymphoma is the most common association) The Marsh classification is used to categorize celiac disease into different types and to quantify 
severity of disease involvement.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient who presented with severe malabsorption is found to be positive for IgA tissue 
trans-glutaminase antibodies. What will be the next best step?
questions.explanation:
In this patient with positive serology, a biopsy should be done next, to confirm the diagnosis of 
celiac disease. Tissue transglutaminase Ab (tTG-IgA) is the best screening test. IgA endomysial antibodies (EMA) 
are most specific. But a small-intestinal biopsy is required to establish a diagnosis of celiac disease, before starting 
treatment.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 30-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. IgA tissue 
trans-glutaminase antibodies were found to be positive. Duodenal biopsy revealed the 
following. Which of the following complications would you not expect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario along with the presence of IgA tissue trans-glutaminase antibodies and biopsy 
showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates indicate a case of celiac 
disease. Pancreatic insufficiency is not a complication of celiac disease. The complications of celiac disease are: • Intestinal lymphomas • Intestinal ulcers- also known as ulcerative jejunoileitis • Collagenous sprue- development of a subepithelial collagen layer

questions.question: Question 17: When will you diagnose a patient with refractory celiac disease?

options.a: No remission of disease despite gluten free diet
options.d: Development of a subepithelial collagen layer

questions.explanation:
Refractory celiac disease is diagnosed when there is no remission of disease despite a strict 
gluten-free diet for 6-12 months. Patients are symptomatic and have persistent small intestinal villous atrophy on biopsy. They 
respond well to steroids.

questions.question: Question 19: All are true about Whipple's disease except :

options.a: Caused by gram positive organism Tropheryma whipplei
options.b: Culture of organism from biopsy specimen helps in early diagnosis

questions.explanation:
Tropheryma whipplei is difficult to culture from the biopsy specimen. Hence, it cannot be used for 
the early diagnosis of Whipple's disease. Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by the gram-positive bacteria 
Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with central nervous system 
& cardiac problems. It mostly affects men and presents with fever, diarrhea weight loss, and 
arthralgia. The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows the presence of 
PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine and other organs with evidence of disease.

questions.question: Question 20: What is the most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease is progressive dementia. Other important CNS manifestations in Whipple's disease are: • Personality and mood changes • Progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia • Focal neurologic presentations 434 
Sold by @itachibot • Oculomasticatory myorrhythmia - an unusual combination of rhythmic eye and jaw movements 
which is pathognomonic of Whipple's disease. Whipple's disease associated with CNS symptoms has a poor prognosis. Note: Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with 
neuroblastoma.

questions.question:
Question 21: What is the most common cardiovascular presentation seen in patients with Whipple's 
disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common cardiovascular presentation in Whipple's disease is culture-negative 
endocarditis. Other cardiovascular findings include: • Congestive heart failure • Pericarditis • Myocarditis

questions.question:
Question 22: A 38-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and joint pains. A duodenal 
biopsy was done. Which of the following drug is used in the maintenance phase of treatment 
of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows PAS-positive foamy macrophages present in the lamina propria. This 
along with the given features suggests Whipple's disease. Cotrimoxazole is used in the 
maintenance phase of the treatment of Whipple's disease. Treatment of Whipple's disease: • Induction phase- ceftriaxone or meropenem or penicillin G + streptomycin - 2 weeks • Maintenance phase- trimethoprim / sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) for 1 year. It has high CNS 
penetration so it is used in maintenance to prevent relapse. 435 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: A 42-year-old man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. 
Celiac serology was negative. Biopsy of the small intestinal mucosa revealed villous atrophy 424 
Sold by @itachibot and crypt hyperplasia with normal mucosal thickness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The history of malabsorptive symptoms, a negative celiac serology, and the biopsy findings are 
suggestive of tropical sprue. Improvement in symptoms after folic acid intake is a hallmark of tropical sprue. Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious aetiology. It is seen 
in people from the tropics such as India, Southeast Asia and South America. Tropical sprue and celiac disease have similar clinical, endoscopic and histologic findings. 
However, a positive celiac serology (anti-tissue transglutaminase and anti-endomysial antibodies) 
can be used to rule out tropical sprue.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following would you prescribe for a patient with tropical sprue?
questions.explanation:
The treatment of tropical sprue is tetracycline + folic acid. Because of marked folate deficiency, folic acid is most often given together with broad spectrum 
antibiotics for up to 6 months.

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following drug is used for the management of a patient with small intestinal 
bacterial overgrowth?
questions.explanation:
Rifaximin is the preferred drug for the management of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth 
(SIBO). The antibiotics are given for around 3 weeks. The other drugs that can be used are : • Tetracyclines • Cephalosporins • Metronidazole • Amoxicillin-Clavulanic acid Rifaximin is the antibiotic used in hepatic encephalopathy to lower blood ammonia levels. 436 
Sold by @itachibot Other Gastrointestinal Conditions
